The term 'sense consciousness' is used in the morning chanting, but I didn't hear that [in MN 19]. When the Buddha recognizes a thought and puts it into a certain bin, this seems like a step beyond sense consciousness.
One of my favorite things about the sutta [MN 19] is where [the Buddha] says, “Before I was awakened, it occured to me, ‘Suppose I divide my thoughts into two classes.’” It's like an experiment.
I got a little confused about the part [of MN 19] where it says, 'these thoughts are not to be feared.'
In trying to stop thinking, there's an incredible tension that is created in the mind.
[MN 19] mentioned that these thoughts might make you tired.
That [MN 19.8] feels like it goes to the Four Foundations of Mindfulness of knowing when the mind is here, knowing what's happening to the body.
Appreciation for the similies of poking the cow and the herd of deer (MN 19).
Sometimes I get very worried and keep thinking about something and get tired and stressed out. Is this what the Buddha meant by 'a day and a night' [in MN 19.8]?
Could you give some advice on using directed and sustained thought? Would these thoughts be like reapeating 'Buddho' or are they conceptual?

I'm curious about the wholesome/unwholesome assessment [in MN 19]. If it's a thought of ill-will, greed, hatred, or delusion, but we're not attached to it, we're just seeing it arise, seeing it pass, recognizing it, being aware that it's in the mind. Does the unwholesomeness come from believing it?
How much should we be using that tool of the two categories?
In this teaching [MN 19], the Buddha doesn't talk about any middle ground such as neutral thoughts.
Where does attachment fit into the Dvedhāvitakka Sutta [MN 19]? Is it also thought?
When [the Buddha] talks about sensual desire, that's craving, right?
Do you know what the Pāli word used for sensual desire [in MN 19] is? I think that craving and sensual desire are different.

The last option [in MN 20] I thought was really interesting because it's rare I hear such agressive terms used. There's almost a sense of violence in some of those terms. Is that just because of the interpretation? Also, is another option to get rid of the thought to get up and actively do something?
Ajahn Amaro talked about a teacher who was an ex-boxer with rough manners.
Ajahn Mun admonishes Ajahn Mahā Boowa: "You need to develop some subtlety!"

After a long time in practice trying to order thoughts around, which hasn't been so fruitful, there's been an experiment: trying to observe even when thoughts are really spinning, just bringing an awareness and let them spin. If there's a strong sense of watching, where does that fit in [to MN 20]?
When you go into your body to feel the underlying emotion behnd a thought, what happens when the bodily feeling is so uncomfortable that you really don't want to feel it?
It seems really difficult to think of Dhamma or the refuges while in such a wrapped-up state. I don't know if I could do that.
I've discovered on this path that we can change, but sometimes we can not change, and it's just accepting ourselves better and being more at ease in our bodies.
I'm struggling with developing a personal faith that I can trust in my body and not hurt myself and accept myself.
One time I really to the edge of all kinds of sadness and my mind came up with [audio unclear] and Three Refuges in a way that seemed very useful for me.

All these practices [in MN 20] have been useful to calm the thoughts in the moment, but with ill-will and forgiveness, it hasn't genuinely changed the underlying emotion. I thought I had forgiven somebody, but ill-will comes up towards that person six months later. When do you genuinely change the underlying emotion?
When the word evil comes up in a Buddhist context, it always takes me by surprise. What is the word being translated as evil thoughts [in MN 20]?
How can you connect the five methods [of MN 20] with the development of insight, which people tend to equate with just observing?
about developing faith in the practice by watching energies move, change, and dissipate in the body.
The language in method five [of MN 20] still catches me. If I'm pushing against a thought and beating it down, I'm actually more attached to it because of that.
I find the method of tracing a thought back to its origin in sense contact very useful.
The fifth method [of MN 20] is using mind on mind, thought over thought. It's actually kind of subtle.
My friend is having anxiety about her pregnancy issues. These are understandable but not helpful for her well-being. Do you have any recommendations for dealing with legitimate fears?
Would this go under the category of taking a smaller peg? (MN 20 method one)
My experience with method five [of MN 20] is that it works when the mind doing the crushing is compassion mind, wisdom mind.
Are the teachings in MN 19: Two Kinds of Thought and MN 20: The Removal of Distracting Thoughts meant to be used just during meditation or 24/7?

Our group talked about body scanning, coming back to the body, as a way to find your center. Everyone was conscious of skillful means in knowing themselves. We all had different ways of knowing what works and adapting to different circumstances that arise.
Our group talked about what we use to deal with our thoughts, the Four Noble Truths, and perfectionism.
"You can't go wrong by coming back to the Four Noble Truths."
The footprint of all animals fit within the footprint of an elephant. In the same way, all the teachings of the Buddha will fit into the Four Noble Truths. — Sariputta, MN 28
Our group talked about our suffering, the kind of thoughts that we're laboring under, the nature of obsessive and addictive thoughts, and how these teachings might help us choose freedom.

Where does allowing the thought to be there for a little bit come in? For example, if you're thinking about a past event that means something to you, and you're trying to stop it, and all of a sudden you realize, 'Oh, it's okay. This is meaningful to you.' And it really loses power.

I've been reflecting on freedom from as opposed to freedom within. Sometimes there's a secret hope that those thoughts will go away, vibhava-taṇha, as opposed to freedom within, meaning releasing the identification with painful thoughts.
Just that much.|Ajahn Chah
Do thoughts by themselves have karmic consequences?
MN 56: Upāli
Is it good kamma to decide not to act on an unskillful thought?
A person talks with Ajahn Liem, analyzing their consistently bad thoughts and obsessions. He replies, "If you see a pile of excrement, why would you want to stick your nose in it?"
I think my problem is that my nose is already in there, and I don't want to realize that I'm so stupid that it's hard to get it out.
When visiting Abhayagiri, Ajahn Liem learns that Ukiah is the nearest town. _Khya_ means "the garbage" in Thai. He later tells the monks, "Don't live in _Khya_."
It's so hard not to identify with the contents of the mind, to not make it me and mine. Realizing how useless so many of my thoughts are helps.
Is there a reason why mindfulness is number seven in the Path?
Is this recorded?
